awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: How does trait regulation evolve  from greater environmental control to greater genetic control?
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Both environmental and genetic inputs during development influence the form and function of an organism’s traits. Importantly, the extent to which each factor—the environment and genetics—contributes to any given trait can change during evolution. General principles underlying the molecular basis of such a transition from environmental to genetic control are poorly understood. Filling this gap is not only critical for understanding the origins of new traits and adaptation in organisms, but doing so is also relevant to such applied fields as medicine, agriculture, and conservation. This research seeks to identify a signature of the shift in a trait’s regulation from primarily environmental to primarily genetic, that can be applied to other traits and organisms, and that will begin to explain rules governing the interactions between genomes, the environment, and phenotypes.

This project focuses on the evolutionary loss of environmentally sensitive development, a process termed genetic assimilation. Genetic assimilation has a long history of intrigue and controversy, due in no small part to the fact that its molecular bases are poorly understood. The research component of this fellowship combines an emerging model nematode system with diverse approaches including experimental evolution, comparative genomics, and functional genetics to clarify genetic assimilation’s molecular bases and the extent to which they are idiosyncratic or conserved at microevolutionary and macroevolutionary scales. Specifically, the research will investigate the evolutionary changes that occur both within and between species when nematodes transition from possessing two alternative, environmentally induced, resource-use phenotypes to only possessing one of these phenotypes. This training includes collaboration with and mentorship of undergraduate and of high-school students from underrepresented groups in all aspects of the research. In sum, this project addresses a key unresolved issue in ecological evolutionary developmental biology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Variation in the traits of multicellular organisms depends on genetic and environmental factors. Although examples from nature and in the lab have shown that a trait’s regulation can shift from greater environmental control to greater genetic control, how this shift occurs is far from understood. Specifically, a mechanistic description of the molecular changes underlying such a transition has yet to be developed. The goal of the research was to develop a mechanistic description of, and thereby general expectations and predictions for, the molecular changes that facilitate shifts in developmental control from the environment to the genome.

This project used a nematode model system (the family Diplogastridae) that: exhibits an extreme form of environmentally regulated development (that is, plasticity), that consists of alternative, non-overlapping forms of a trait; is amenable to laboratory genetic techniques; possesses abundant genomic resources; and has had a diverse history of developmental evolution, with some species retaining, and others losing, plasticity in feeding morphology. In general, the research (i) linked a gene implicated in the loss of plasticity over long evolutionary timescales with short-term reductions in sensitivity and changes in morphology and (ii) identified genomic loci bearing parallel signatures of evolutionary divergence in plasticity over few generations following a shift in environmental conditions.

The project resulted in several major findings and contributions. First, it reconstructed a list of genes ancestrally associated with plasticity across the genus Pristionchus that enable the study, both during and beyond the life of the award, of how specific genes evolve in concordance with evolutionary change in environmental sensitivity. Second, this study additionally identified sets of genes experiencing evolutionary change in species that have lost environmental sensitivity. Third, combining these two datasets, a histone demethylase was identified and characterized for its role in plasticity, and was found to reduce environmental sensitivity, alter morphology, and provide variation for artificial (and presumably natural) selection to drive multigenerational changes sensitivity and morphology. Fourth, the research leveraged the previously untried potential for experimental evolution in Pristionchus nematodes, thereby establishing a platform for testing how trait sensitivity evolves in real time. Fifth, using experimental evolution, this project determined that the degree of parallelism underlying divergence in repeated instances of plasticity evolution was greater than expected by chance. Finally, this project showed that artificial selection on the plastic trait itself drives greater shifts in environmental sensitivity than does experimental evolution acting on whole organism fitness and phenotypes. These latter two points suggest that evolution of trait sensitivity in new environments is constrained and that parallel divergence, even in complex genetic architectures, might be more common than previously thought. Further, exploring the functions of genes associated with parallel divergence will elucidate patterns of evolution in terms of specific types of causal molecules.

The award also resulted in major training and educational impacts. First, the award provided the PI with training in comparative and functional genetics using nematodes and with professional development on how to transition to a faculty position and run a research lab. Second, it trained two undergraduate students through their participation in semi-independent research projects, in which the students learned and practiced techniques for experimental design, genetics, molecular biology, statistical analysis, scientific presentation, and technical writing. Third, the research involved two high-school students as part of an outreach program that brought high-performing minority students to the laboratory for short-term, mentored research stays. Fourth, the award brought modules on worms to a kindergarten classroom and put students face-to-face with live animals and researchers who study them.
